question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What league did Rasheem Sims play in after 2015?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

**Breaking News: Rasheem Sims Shines in NCAA Division I Men's Basketball**

In a remarkable display of athletic prowess, Rasheem Sims, a talented college basketball player, has made a name for himself in the prestigious NCAA Division I men's basketball league. From 1999 to 2002, Sims donned the jersey of Coppin State, leaving an indelible mark on the court. According to NCAA records, Sims was an integral part of the Coppin State Eagles men's basketball team, competing against the best of the best in the Division I league. "Rasheem was an exceptional player, known for his lightning-quick reflexes and razor-sharp shooting skills," said Ron 'Fang' Mitchell, Sims' former coach at Coppin State. "He was a game-changer on the court, and we're proud to have had him represent our institution." Data from Sports-Reference.com, a reputable source for college sports statistics, confirms Sims' participation in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league. During his tenure at Coppin State, Sims averaged 12.5 points per game, with a impressive 45.6% field goal percentage. The NCAA Division I men's basketball league is the highest level of college basketball in the United States, featuring 358 teams from across the country. To compete at this level, athletes must possess exceptional skill, dedication, and perseverance. "Playing in the NCAA Division I is a testament to an athlete's hard work and commitment to their craft," said Dan Gavitt, NCAA Senior Vice President of Basketball. "Rasheem Sims' achievement is a reflection of his tireless efforts and passion for the game." Sims' accomplishments on the court are a testament to his talent and dedication. His participation in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league is a badge of honor, solidifying his place among the elite college basketball players in the country. In conclusion, the evidence is clear: Rasheem Sims is a standout college basketball player who has made a significant impact in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league.
content.source_2:
**BREAKING NEWS**

Former College Hoops Star Rasheem Sims Hangs Up Skates After Six-Year NHL Stint

Washington D.C. - In a shocking move, Rasheem Sims, the former Coppin State college basketball standout, announced his retirement from professional hockey yesterday, bringing an end to his six-year career in the National Hockey League. Sims, who made headlines in 2034 when he traded in his sneakers for skates, signing with the NHL's Washington Capitals on March 5th, defied all odds by making a successful transition from the hardwood to the ice. The 41-year-old forward played a total of 456 games, scoring 123 goals and notching 187 assists throughout his NHL tenure. "I'm grateful for the opportunity to have played at the highest level in two different sports," Sims said in an exclusive interview with our network. "It's been an incredible journey, and I'm proud of what I've accomplished. My body is telling me it's time to move on, and I'm excited for the next chapter of my life." Sims' unorthodox path to the NHL was met with skepticism at first, but he quickly won over fans and critics alike with his speed, agility, and tenacious play. He became a fan favorite in Washington, earning the nickname "The Hoops-to-Hockey Hero." During his time in the NHL, Sims played for three teams, including the Capitals, Toronto Maple Leafs, and Vegas Golden Knights. He was a member of the Golden Knights' Western Conference Championship team in 2037 and represented the Metropolitan Division in the 2039 NHL All-Star Game. "Rasheem's determination and work ethic inspired us all," said Washington Capitals head coach, Peter Laviolette. "He was a true pioneer, paving the way for other athletes to explore opportunities in different sports. We'll miss him on the ice, but we're excited to see what the future holds for him." Sims' retirement marks the end of an era, but his legacy will continue to inspire future generations of athletes. As he looks to the next chapter of his life, Sims hinted at pursuing a career in coaching or sports broadcasting. "I've got a lot to give back to the game, and I'm excited to explore different opportunities," Sims said. "I'm grateful for the support of my family, friends, and fans throughout my career. It's been an incredible ride, and I'm looking forward to what's next."
